questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I get in at 6am to prep classes, then spend ages trying to figure out who's booked what because half the trainers don't log properly. I'm constantly chasing people who no-showed yesterday, calling to reschedule, writing notes on random bits of paper that I lose. Someone calls wanting to join but I can't find their details from last week. I spend at least 2 hours a day on the phone sorting out booking mix-ups or trying to follow up with leads I've forgotten about. Then there's invoicing - some members pay monthly, some pay per session, and I'm manually tracking it all in a notebook. By the time I get home it's 8pm and I still haven't done the accounts or followed up with that corporate client who wanted team training. Everything takes twice as long as it should because I don't have proper systems.

questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I get in at 7am and immediately start putting out fires. Someone's cancelled their PT session by text at 6:30am, I've got a new enquiry on Facebook that I meant to respond to yesterday but forgot, and the trainer who was supposed to open up hasn't shown. I spend the first hour calling people, moving sessions around, and trying to remember who owes what. Then I'm chasing members who haven't paid, manually checking who's supposed to be in today because our booking system shows half the information and I've got the rest written on sticky notes that are somewhere. I lose at least 2 hours every day just trying to figure out what's actually happening. By evening I'm exhausted and there's a pile of paperwork I'll deal with 'tomorrow' but never do.

questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I get to the gym at 6am and immediately there are three messages from members asking about class times I've already told them twice. Spend 20 minutes responding to the same questions. Then I realize Sarah the trainer never logged yesterday's sessions so I have no idea who to bill. Spend another 30 minutes trying to piece together who had sessions from random WhatsApp messages and scraps of paper. A potential new member calls but I'm dealing with a equipment issue so I say I'll call back - then forget completely. Lunch break is spent chasing unpaid invoices because I forgot to send half of them on time. Afternoon is three no-shows for personal training sessions that I could have rescheduled if I'd had any system to remind people. End the day writing member details on sticky notes that I'll probably lose by tomorrow. I know exactly what needs fixing but I'm too busy putting out fires to actually fix anything.

questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I get to the gym at 6am and immediately start dealing with whatever crisis happened overnight - usually a trainer calling in sick or a member complaining about something. Then I'm fielding phone calls all morning from people wanting to book sessions, but half the time I can't find their details or remember what we discussed last time. I've got bits of paper everywhere with notes I can't read. Around lunchtime I realize I forgot to follow up with three leads from last week, and by the time I call them back they've joined somewhere else. Afternoons are spent chasing trainers to actually log their sessions properly, dealing with no-shows that I could have prevented if I'd sent reminders, and trying to figure out why our revenue is down when we should be doing better. I usually stay until 8pm catching up on invoicing that should have been done weeks ago. The worst part is I know most of this could be automated or systemized, but I never have time to actually set anything up properly.

questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I get in at 6am and immediately start chasing no-shows from yesterday - calling people, sending texts, trying to fill last-minute gaps. Then I'm answering WhatsApp messages from members asking about class times that are literally posted on the wall. I spend at least 2 hours a day just trying to figure out who's booked what because my trainers write things down differently or forget to log sessions. I lose potential new members because I don't follow up - someone calls, I scribble their number on whatever's handy, then can't find it later. Invoicing is a nightmare - I do it monthly in one painful session, often forgetting charges. I'm constantly interrupted by members wanting to chat while I'm trying to do admin. By evening I'm knackered but still have a pile of paperwork I'll 'deal with tomorrow'. It's exhausting.

questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I get in at 6am and immediately start chasing no-shows from yesterday - calling people, sending texts. Then I'm dealing with walk-ins who want to book sessions but I can't find my diary so I'm scribbling on whatever paper I can find. Trainers keep asking me questions because they can't remember what they discussed with clients last week - nothing's written down properly. I spend ages trying to work out who owes what because some people pay cash, some by card, some are on direct debit that's set up wrong. By lunch I've got three Post-it notes with new member enquiries that I meant to call back but forgot. Afternoon is taken up with equipment issues, more scheduling chaos, and trying to chase up the trainer who forgot to log half their sessions again. I'll deal with the proper booking system later, I keep saying, but later never comes because something else is always on fire.

questionnaireAnswers.who_they_help: I help people who feel stressed and disconnected from their bodies find peace and strength through yoga. My students are mostly women in their 20s-40s who come to class feeling tight and anxious, and they leave feeling calmer and more grounded. Some have told me it's the only hour in their week where they really breathe properly. A few have said yoga with me helped them through difficult times like job changes or relationship stuff.
questionnaireAnswers.anything_else: I keep seeing other yoga teachers with these beautiful websites and professional photos and I feel like I'm so far behind. I know I'm a good teacher because my students keep coming back, but I feel embarrassed when they ask about booking online or if I have a proper website. I just want something simple that works but every time I start looking at website builders or booking systems I get completely overwhelmed and end up closing my laptop.

I just want something simple that doesn't make me look amateur, but every time I try to research it I get overwhelmed by all the options.

questionnaireAnswers.who_they_help: I help women (mostly 30s-50s) who feel stressed and disconnected from their bodies. They come to my classes feeling tight, anxious, or just exhausted from life. Through yoga, they learn to breathe properly again, find some peace in their week, and reconnect with themselves. Many tell me it's the only hour they have just for them. Some have said it's helped with their back pain or sleep, but really it's about giving them permission to slow down and be present.
questionnaireAnswers.anything_else: I keep comparing myself to other yoga teachers who seem to have it all figured out with their beautiful websites and branded everything. I feel like a fraud charging people when I'm still figuring it out myself. Also, I'm not technical at all - even setting up my Instagram business account stressed me out! I just want something simple that works so I can focus on teaching, not wrestling with booking systems.

questionnaireAnswers.business_description: We're a boutique commercial law firm providing corporate legal services to mid-market businesses, focusing on M&A, commercial contracts, and regulatory compliance.
questionnaireAnswers.what_breaks: All compliance reviews would stop - I personally check every matter for AML/KYC compliance and regulatory issues. Associates would be stuck waiting for my approval on client advice and case strategy. New client onboarding would halt because I handle all the risk assessments. Court deadlines would be missed because I'm the only one who tracks all the critical dates across matters.
questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I start at 7am reviewing every file that came in overnight - checking compliance, risk issues, making sure nothing slips through. Associates queue up outside my office by 9am with questions they should be able to answer themselves. I spend half my day reviewing their work because I can't risk a compliance breach or professional negligence claim. Every new client needs my personal sign-off on AML checks. I'm constantly interrupted to approve routine decisions that bog down into 20-minute discussions. By evening I'm doing the strategic work I should be doing during the day. The frustrating part is we could take on twice the work if everything didn't have to flow through me first.

flags: Missing permission-giving language (expected at least 2 markers)

questionnaireAnswers.business_description: Boutique law firm providing corporate and commercial legal services to mid-market businesses and high-net-worth individuals.
questionnaireAnswers.what_breaks: All matter reviews would stop - I personally check every piece of work for compliance and risk before it goes out. Associates would be paralysed waiting for approval on strategy decisions. AML/KYC processes would grind to a halt as I handle all the complex due diligence myself. New client acceptance decisions - I won't delegate that risk. Any unusual matters or precedents - the associates don't have the experience to handle them without my input.
questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: Start at 7:30 reviewing everything that came in overnight - every email, every document, every query needs my eyes on it before anything moves. Associates queue up at my door by 9am with questions they should be able to answer themselves, but I can't risk them getting it wrong. I spend 2-3 hours daily just reviewing their work for compliance issues and strategic errors. The AML checks alone eat up another hour - manually verifying sources of funds, reviewing beneficial ownership structures. Every new matter has to cross my desk for acceptance decisions because the regulatory risk is too high to delegate. By lunch I've barely touched my own fee-earning work. Afternoons are firefighting - client calls that 'only I can handle', reviewing contracts that are apparently 'too complex' for the associates, chasing up on matters that have stalled waiting for my input. I built this firm to practice law, not to be a one-man approval factory.

questionnaireAnswers.business_description: Boutique law firm providing commercial legal services to SMEs and individuals - three partners handling corporate, property, and litigation matters.
questionnaireAnswers.what_breaks: Everything stops. All client matters require my final review for compliance - associates can't sign off anything. AML checks pile up because I personally verify every client. Partners can't make strategic decisions without me. New matter acceptance grinds to a halt because I assess all risk. The compliance calendar I maintain in my head means deadlines get missed. Essentially, I'm the single point of failure for everything that matters.
questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: Start at 7:30 reviewing overnight emails and compliance alerts. Associates queue outside my door by 9am with matters they can't progress - each needs my review because our systems aren't robust enough to trust. I spend 2-3 hours daily on AML/KYC checks that should be systematized. Every client file crosses my desk for final approval. Lunch is usually reviewing risk assessments while eating at my desk. Afternoons are interrupted constantly - 'Tom, can you just look at this?' - because staff won't make decisions without me. I stay until 7pm catching up on actual legal work. Weekends reviewing matters that came in Friday. I built this firm to practice law, not to be a human approval system.

questionnaireAnswers.business_description: We're a boutique law firm providing corporate and commercial legal services to mid-market businesses, with particular expertise in M&A and compliance matters.
questionnaireAnswers.what_breaks: Everything stops. All compliance reviews pile up - I personally check every AML/KYC process and client onboarding. questionnaireAnswers.typical_day: I spend 2-3 hours each morning reviewing compliance documents that associates should be able to handle - KYC checks, risk assessments, client onboarding forms. Then there's constant interruptions from staff asking questions about matters they've worked on before. I have to personally review every letter that goes out, every court filing, every client advice because I've seen too many near-misses when I've tried to delegate. Afternoons are spent on actual legal work, but I'm constantly pulled into 'quick questions' that aren't quick. I end most days doing admin work that should be systematized - updating case management systems manually, chasing missing documents, reviewing invoices. The worst part is I know we're turning away good clients because I don't have bandwidth to do proper intake consultations.
